intro: Encelia collodes, commonly known as the desert sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and robust, hairy stems. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations such as succulent leaves and deep root systems to conserve water. Its yellow-orange flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Encelia collodes is also valued for its ornamental appeal and resilience in challenging climates.
